content.body: Didn't know they had a pool. I went more by Google Maps rating.

> <@shuyuguo:matrix.org> more than 4% of page visits use dynamic import alone

Is it possible to know what % of page loads are using other user-land module systems? I.e. webpack chunks or require.js.

Because 4% of all page loads is good, but if we knew that 50% of all page loads were basic HTML docs that didn't use any module system, then we could say that adoption amongst the target audience is more like 8% (twice as good).
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @shuyuguo:matrix.org
more than 4% of page visits use dynamic import alone

Is it possible to know what % of page loads are using other user-land module systems? I.e. webpack chunks or require.js.

Because 4% of all page loads is good, but if we knew that 50% of all page loads were basic HTML docs that didn't use any module system, then we could say that adoption amongst the target audience is more like 8% (twice as good).

content.body: FYI the decimal proposal will be hosting an incubator call on Thursday, July 29, at 15:00 UTC. Anyone interested in (decimal) numbers is welcome to attend. The meeting will last at most one hour. https://github.com/tc39/incubator-agendas/pull/30
use counters are, how do i say, "very dumb"
i don't think it's feasible to add any _browser_-level instrumentation for any userland pattern
content.formatted_body: i don't think it's feasible to add any browser-level instrumentation for any userland pattern

content.body: Ehhh it depends, but generally yes. You can do some surprising amounts of detection, but it has to be relatively cheap. (CSS stuff, for example, is already expensive enough that use counters can do a decent amount before they become troublesome.)
July 29th is a Saturday, so I assume they meant June.
the PR correctly says June: v
